title: How to Destroy CDs and DVDs: A Step-by-Step Guide

steps.title: Fold and bust.
steps.content: Fold and bust. Wrap the discs with plastic wrap and then fold it until it breaks. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Shred the discs with a disc shredder.
steps.content: Shred the discs with a disc shredder. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Cut the discs.
steps.content: Cut the discs. You can use a pair of scissors, but be careful as the foil will flake. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Break the discs.
steps.content: Break the discs. Wrap the discs with a towel and use a kick or a hammer to destroy the disc. The towel is used to protect you.

steps.title: Cut the discs with a knife.
steps.content: Cut the discs with a knife.

steps.title: Center punch the discs.
steps.content: Center punch the discs. Punch at least 12 holes on the discs.

steps.title: Microwave the discs.
steps.content: Microwave the discs. Place the disc into a microwave and set it for 5-10 seconds, or until you see sparks. The microwave cannot be used for food after that. [4] X Research source Always use adult supervision when doing this step.

steps.title: Use a blow torch to melt the discs.
steps.content: Use a blow torch to melt the discs. Do in a safe area using proper safety gear. The ground on which the CDs sit should be flameproof, such as concrete.

steps.title: Erase the discs with the computer, if the disc is rewritable and the computer has a CD-RW drive.
steps.content: Erase the discs with the computer, if the disc is rewritable and the computer has a CD-RW drive.

steps.title: Cover the disc with duct tape, then rip it off.
steps.content: Cover the disc with duct tape, then rip it off. This does not work on all discs.

steps.title: Sand the discs.
steps.content: Sand the discs. Use a belt sander on the top side of the disc. This should be done in an easy-to-clean area.

steps.title: Wipe with acetone.
steps.content: Wipe with acetone. Soak a cotton pad in pure acetone, then wipe the bottom of the disc with it. It should become frosted and unreadable. [5] X Research source
